thread.title: Trying to get fit? A buddy can help
thread.title_full: Trying to get fit? A buddy can help

author: YMCA
title: Trying to get fit? A buddy can help
text:
Turns out the exercise itself isn't the hard part. "Often the biggest hurdle for someone looking to start working out is getting to the gym and building a weekly routine," said Laura Fasano, vice president of healthy living at the YMCA of Greater Rochester.
Fasano, a 25-year veteran of the YMCA, shared several ways to help you stick to a routine by connecting with an exercise buddy.
Consistency Counts
Fasano has found that when members schedule set times to meet at the Y, it helps them make a commitment to fitness and keep it. "It pushes you to hold yourself accountable and creates a social opportunity to connect and have fun," she explained.
Challenge Each Other
When you work out with a friend, you'll likely be starting at different levels and abilities. But as long as you're surrounded by people who are supportive of your healthy living and wellness goals, the disparity can actually help. You might be pushed to your limits, and you'll learn new skills.
Experience New Classes
Group exercise can be intimidating, especially when it involves new types of equipment or movements. Yet new options (Fasano mentioned offerings such as TRX Suspension training , Les Mills' GRIT , Zumba, and BodyPump) can be the best way to establish a routine that will stay interesting. Attending with a buddy can ease some of the sense of intimidation, providing some confidence and encouragement when you need it most.
Create and Reinforce Healthy Habits
Healthy activities and behaviors don't need to end once your workout does. When you're socializing with your workout buddy, you can help each other maintain positive behaviors by expanding them beyond your fitness facility. Create a well-rounded, balanced lifestyle by choosing healthy, fresh foods and fun activities. And don't forget to reward yourself in a motivational way for all your hard work.
Celebrate Small and Large Successes Together
Did you increase your squat weight, improve your run time, or complete your first pull-up? Your workout buddy will share your excitement and sense of achievement, whether small or large, knowing how hard you pushed to achieve your goal.

Laura Fasano has been with the YMCA of Greater Rochester for the past 25 years. As vice president for Healthy Living, she is responsible for leading program development, quality standards and program training, with a primary focus on health innovation. She is leading the YMCA of Greater Rochester in its new phase of health initiatives that include chronic-disease prevention and strategic partnerships in the Rochester community.
